description: n such C(n,3) = C(x,3) + C(y,3) is solvable.
comments: Bombieri's Napkin Problem: Bombieri said that "the equation C(x,n)+C(y,n)=C(z,n) has no trivial solutions for n >= 3" (the joke being that he said "trivial" rather than "nontrivial"!).
references: J. Leech, Some solutions of Diophantine equations, Proc. Camb. Phil. Soc., 53 (1957), 778-780.
Van der Poorten, Notes on Fermat's Last Theorem, Wiley, p. 122.
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n=1..463 (n < 10^6)
